prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Business information is produced as a result of the expenditure of effort, time, labour and resources. For that reason, protection will be extended even when the materials necessary to produce the information are in the public domain. The key factor is that the information be “the product of work, or expenditure of money, or of trial and error, or the expenditure of time”.[1] This element of confidential business information was set forth in the leading English case of Saltman Engineering Co. v. Campbell Engineering Co.:

On the other hand, it is perfectly possible to have a confidential document, be it a formula, a plan, a sketch, or something of that kind, which is the result of work done by the maker on materials which may be available for the use of anybody: but what makes it confidential is the fact that the maker of the document has used his brain and thus produced a result which can only be produced by somebody who goes through the same process.[2] (Emphasis added.)

In another major English decision, Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd.,[3] the court specifically acknowledged that it is the effort expended and the ingenuity involved, even in the face of commonplace components, that will qualify information as valuable to a business.[4] In fact, simpler and more commonplace concepts often have greater need of protection.[5] However, as held in Coco, there must be some basic “ingenuity” or “discovery” involved:

Something that has been constructed solely from materials in the public domain may possess the necessary quality of confidentiality; for something new and confidential may have been brought into being by the application of the skill and ingenuity of the human brain. Novelty depends on the thing itself, and not upon the quality of its constituent parts. Indeed, often more striking the novelty, the more commonplace its components.[6]

In Plaza Consulting Inc. v. Grieve,[7] the plaintiff failed to address in a credible way the key first question of whether the information used by its former employees was proprietary at all. Much of what was characterized as confidential information that had been misappropriated by the former employees was not created by the Plaintiff at all, but by their former clients. The documents in question were little more than a list of technology questions and issues, and responses to those issues, encountered by the plaintiff's clients. They were the type of operational outlines that would be created by virtually any consultant servicing those clients, and were created specifically by the clients themselves so that their technology consultants would provide focused service. The clients provided the same information to the defendants as they had provided to the Plaintiff, and they raised no complaint about the defendants using it.[8]

In Scott & Associates Engineering Ltd. v. Finavera Renewables Inc.,[9] a property was offered for sale in a bid system where many were invited to participate. The plaintiff conducted research on the project, was accepted as a qualified bidder, submitted four offers in its own name and eventually became the only entity with which Penn West was still negotiating. Penn West acknowledged that the plaintiff had become the preferred potential purchaser of the project. However, the plaintiff did not have the required funds or necessary financing and Scott actively sought monies from numerous sources. Eventually, the plaintiff and the defendant were brought together and they moved quickly to acquire the project, with the defendant providing the money. The plaintiff and the defendant shared information, worked together, and submitted a bid in the name of the defendant in the same amount as in prior offers by the plaintiff. This final bid was eventually accepted by Penn West. Differences of opinion arose and the tensions were such that when the purchase and sale transaction closed with Penn West, the defendant purported to have acquired the wind project on its own account. The defendant subsequently developed the project alone, hired another engineering firm to work on the project, and eventually sold the project to a third party, all without any further involvement of the plaintiff. People who came to this existing opportunity were provided with extensive materials compiled and owned by Penn West. Potential purchasers were expected to make their own evaluations and/or further enquire and satisfy themselves in the manner of their choice about the attractiveness, economics and viability of the project.[10]

A party alleging a breach of confidence only has a right over information which he or she has created with some measure of his or her own time, skill and effort. There is no obligation of confidence where the party asserting the right had no part in creating the information but merely summarized the information made public by a third party.[11] The great majority of the information provided to the defendant was the confidential information of Penn West and was not created by the plaintiff. The plaintiff merely passed it along or summarized it. Therefore, there was no obligation of confidence owed by the defendant to the plaintiff for Penn West's information.[12]

The trial judge also found merit to the defendant's claim that the plaintiff gave information to so many potential investors that it did not retain the necessary quality of confidence, if it ever had it. The evidence was not clear what went to whom or under what conditions of confidentiality. Such distribution diluted the claim of confidentiality and despite the number of people to whom the plaintiff sent those documents, they always were and continued to remain the confidential information of Penn West.[13]

There was therefore only a small amount of the plaintiff's information that had any quality of confidence about it that could be enforced. This included the amount the plaintiff bid in its offers; the few terms the plaintiff had negotiated with Penn West outside its proposed Purchase and Sale Agreement, and information the plaintiff requested and received from Golder on wildlife and other issues.[14] The defendant used the information provided by the plaintiff in the negotiation and close of the acquisition of the project.[15] However, the trial judge concluded that the defendant had not misused the plaintiff's confidential information in putting forward the final offer in its name alone, or in negotiating the terms and closing of the Purchase and Sale Agreement, stating:

… These were not prohibited uses of the confidential information because I find they were done with Scott's knowledge and consent at the time the final offer was made to Penn West. The use of confidential information cannot become a misuse of information retroactively; that is, at the time Finavera used the confidential information, it was done with Scott's consent and cooperation. That Scott did not receive its payment or owner's engineer contract does not support a finding of misuse of the confidential information it gave to Finavera for the express intended purposes that Finavera could make an offer to acquire the project in its name alone.[16]
The plaintiff could not establish that it was entitled to an accounting for profit or constructive trust in the project based on a breach of confidence. The trial judge stated:

This is not a case that fell neatly within the case law on breaches of confidence based on the misuse of confidential information. While I am prepared to assume that Finavera used the information Scott supplied, I have concluded that only a very few pieces of information supplied by Scott were Scott's, as opposed to Penn West's, confidential information and such was used as the parties intended: that is to allow Finavera to purchase the project.

As previously stated, I do not see that the gravamen of this case is about a breach of the duty of loyalty or a breach of the duty of confidence, but rather an unjust enrichment in the amount of Scott's efforts and the “springboard” effect that he provided for Finavera to acquire the project.[17]
Accordingly, the compensation awarded to the plaintiff was awarded only on the claim of unjust enrichment.

In Scott & Associates Engineering Ltd. v. Ghost Pine Windfarm, LP,[18] the application judge granted Ghost Pine's summary dismissal application and dismissed Scott's claim in its entirety. Scott and Finavera worked together on a bid for a wind farm project. Ultimately, Finavera was the successful bidder and developed the project. Finavera did not include Scott in the final bid, nor did it hire Scott as the engineer for the project. Scott sued Finavera alleging that Finavera had misused confidential information Scott had provided as part of the joint bid process; misappropriated Scott's business opportunity; and been unjustly enriched by Scott's efforts in relation to the purchase of the project.[19]

Finavera sold part of the project to Ghost Pine. Scott then sued Ghost Pine. Scott alleged that Ghost Pine made the purchase with full knowledge of Scott's lawsuit against Finavera, including its allegations that Finavera held the project in trust for Scott. It argued that as a result of this knowledge when making the purchase, Ghost Pine now held the project and the associated lands for Scott as constructive trustee. Scott also alleged that Ghost Pine knowingly received confidential information from Finavera and benefitted from this information. It sought a constructive trust in its favour over Ghost Pine's interests in the project and associated lands, an accounting of profits or damages in the alternative.[20]

Ghost Pine brought an application for summary dismissal on the grounds that section 203 of the Land Titles Act was a bar to Scott's claims against the lands. Ghost Pine also argued that the application judge should dismiss Scott's claims for knowing receipt, breach of confidence and unjust enrichment.

The completed Finavera litigation resolved a number of issues. In particular, Justice Martin concluded at trial that Scott had no interest in the lands. Furthermore, since Justice Martin refused to impose a constructive trust as remedy, the motions judge dismissed Scott's claim for knowing receipt of trust property, as there never was a trust interest. The only remaining issues included whether the application judge should summarily dismiss Scott's breach of confidence claim.[21]

In the Finavera litigation, Justice Martin dismissed Scott's claim for breach of confidence. She found that Finavera properly used the limited amount of confidential information Scott supplied to acquire the project. Scott did not appeal this finding, nor was it addressed in its leave application before the Supreme Court of Canada. The application judge observed that Justice Martin had explained that Canadian courts have rejected the view that confidential information should be treated as property. Rather, an action for breach of confidence is rooted in the relationship of confidence rather than the legal characteristics of the information confided. Ghost Pine acquired the project from Finavera in an arm's length transaction in which Scott had no involvement. Ghost Pine had no relationship with Scott until Scott sued Ghost Pine in this litigation. Scott did not convey any confidential information to Ghost Pine; in fact, Scott did not communicate with Ghost Pine at all. Furthermore, there was no evidence to suggest that Ghost Pine misused any information to Scott's detriment. Justice Martin concluded there was no misuse of Scott's confidential information by Finavera. There was no basis for Scott to argue that Ghost Pine, a party with whom it had no dealings, misused its confidential information.[22]
The appellant's appeal of the summary dismissal of its claim for breach of confidence against the respondents was dismissed in Scott & Associates Engineering Ltd v. Ghost Pine Windfarm LP.[23]

In 2007 Scott and Finavera worked together on a bid to purchase a wind farm. Scott did significant upfront work on the deal and shared this information with Finavera, who proceeded to close the purchase without involving Scott or hiring Scott for the project. In 2008, Finavera sold part of the project to Ghost Pine. Scott then sued Ghost Pine in this action, alleging that Ghost Pine made the purchase with full knowledge of Scott's lawsuit against Finavera, and claiming that Ghost Pine held the project as constructive trustee and that Ghost Pine knowingly received Scott's confidential information from Finavera and benefitted from that information. Ghost Pine applied in 2010 for summary dismissal of the Action. At the trial in the Finavera Action, Scott's claim for unjust enrichment was granted and Scott was awarded $600,000. The balance of Scott's claims against Finavera were dismissed. The Finavera trial judge concluded that most of the information provided to Finavera by Scott was not its own confidential information, stating:

There is therefore only a small amount of Scott's information that has any quality of confidence about it that can be enforced by Scott. This includes the amount Scott bid in its offers; the few terms Scott had negotiated with Penn West outside its proposed Purchase and Sale Agreement; and information Scott requested and received from Golder Associates Ltd (“Golder”) on wildlife and other issues.

The Finavera trial judge found that, while the information had been communicated in confidence, Finavera had not misused Scott's confidential information because it had been used with Scott's authorization to acquire the assets. An appeal of the Finavera trial decision was dismissed. After the Supreme Court of Canada dismissed the Finavera leave application in October 2015, the parties provided further submissions to the chambers judge on the summary dismissal application. In October 2017, the chambers judge dismissed Scott's entire claim.[24]

Both the Finavera trial judge and the chambers judge correctly identified the three step test for a breach of confidence claim: the information conveyed must be confidential; the information must have been communicated in confidence; and, the party to whom it was communicated must have misused the information to the detriment of the party who confided it. The Chambers judge noted that the Finavera trial judge dismissed Scott's claim against Finavera for breach of confidence because, “Finavera properly used the limited amount of confidential information Scott supplied to acquire the project” In addressing Scott's claim for breach of confidence against Ghost Pine, the Chambers judge stated that Scott did not convey any confidential information to Ghost Pine; in fact, Scott did not communicate with Ghost Pine at all. Furthermore, there was no evidence to suggest that Ghost Pine misused any information to Scott's detriment. The Chambers judge concluded there was no misuse of Scott's confidential information by Finavera. There was no basis for Scott to argue that Ghost Pine, a party with whom it had no dealings, misused its confidential information.[25]

Scott submitted that the chambers judge erred because it was not fatal to its claim for breach of confidence that Scott did not have any direct dealings with Ghost Pine. Scott submitted that third party recipients of confidential information may be liable where they had actual or constructive knowledge of the impropriety. The chambers judge did not address this issue despite evidence from Ghost Pine that it had notice of Scott's claim against Finavera. Scott pointed to the Asset Purchase Agreement between Finavera and Ghost Pine, which required Finavera to deliver to Ghost Pine all documents relating to the Ghost Pine Project, and contained a $1 million holdback in relation to the Scott litigation. As well, Scott submitted that Ghost Pine provided no direct evidence on the summary judgment application that addressed whether it received any of Scott's confidential information.[26]

In the Court of Appeal's view, the chambers judge erred in dismissing Scott's breach of confidence action on the basis that there had been no direct dealings between Scott and Ghost Pine. Scott could still have a claim against Ghost Pine if it knowingly received Scott's confidential information from Finavera and used that information in a manner not authorized by Scott. The finding by the Finavera trial judge that Finavera did not misuse Scott's confidential information was not an answer to Scott's claim against Ghost Pine. Whether any of Scott's confidential information was misused by Ghost Pine was a different issue.[27]

However, that did not end the matter. Before the Chambers judge, Ghost Pine also submitted that the Finavera trial judge had found that very little information provided by Scott to Finavera was actually confidential information of Scott, and that there was no evidence that any of the identified confidential information had been received by Ghost Pine. The Chambers judge did not address these submissions, as he had dismissed Scott's breach of confidence claim for other reasons. At the appeal hearing, Scott conceded that its claim for breach of confidence was limited to the confidential information identified by the Finavera trial judge, essentially the information from Golder regarding wildlife and other issues. Scott submitted, however, that even had the chambers judge addressed these submissions, the evidentiary record was not sufficient to summarily dismiss the breach of confidence claim on the basis that Ghost Pine did not receive the confidential information. Scott pointed out that the onus is on the applicant for summary dismissal to establish that there is “no merit” to a claim.[28]

The Court of Appeal observed that due, in part, to the way the summary dismissal application unfolded, there was no affidavit evidence from Ghost Pine that directly addressed whether it received any of Scott's confidential information, beyond the fact that no such information was included in Ghost Pine's affidavit of records. Ghost Pine submitted that this was sufficient to ground a summary dismissal application. Its officer had sworn that Ghost Pine had produced all of the relevant and material records relating to the action that it had in its possession, custody or power, and identified all the relevant and material records that it once had, but no longer had, in its power. Moreover, when that officer was cross-examined on the affidavit of records, she confirmed that all documents received from Finavera had been provided to their counsel, and counsel confirmed that all documents from Finavera had been included in the affidavit of records. The Court of Appeal was satisfied there was evidence on the record before the Chambers judge that Ghost Pine never possessed any of Scott's confidential information. Accordingly, the appeal of the summary dismissal of Scott's claim for breach of confidence was dismissed.[29]

The amount of effort or cost expended to produce information is a significant factor that may determine whether information should be protected. For example, in LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.,[30] the majority of the court, in the decision of Sopinka J., following the reasoning in Saltman Engineering Co. v. Campbell Engineering Co.,[31] and Seager v. Copydex Ltd.,[32] stated that where there is some private information produced by the expenditure of effort and the overcoming of difficulties, another party should not get a head start through not having to make a similar effort.[33]

A business relationship may be sufficient, even without an express agreement or written contract between the relevant parties, in order for an action for breach of confidence to succeed. See for example City Commercial Realty (Canada) Ltd. v. Bakich:[34]

An action for breach of confidence is often brought in circumstances in which there is a pre-existing non-contractual relationship or a contemplated contractual relationship. The courts have often taken the position that when information of a commercial or industrial nature is communicated in a business-like manner “with some common object in mind”, the recipient carries a heavy burden if he wishes to deny that here is an obligation of confidence.
